author: kylechun255
title: Great
review:
This set is great. The price is good. The set comes with two minifigures three fish and one shark.

The Value

The set comes with a boat hull which is great for the price. The shark is also nice. The minifigures have nice printing and nice accessories.

The Complete Model

The boat looks great and real. The size is pretty nice to scale and the details are great. There are not too many stickers which is also nice. 

Pros-

-Cheap 

-Boat hull

-Accessories

Cons

-The bottom of the boat hull comes off a little easily

Overall

-The set is pretty good for it's price, value, and the parts included.

author: CoolWaterFish
title: This set is a keeper!
review:
This set has a lot of appeal for the young and old alike.

The boat is sleek with a radar and fish fighting seat that both can spin, and outboards that can be raised and lowered as if you were adjusting the trim in real life.  A male and female angler Minifigure makes it perfect for any child who enjoys boating/fishing.  The fishing rod 'hook' is a small piece that connects to the nose of any of the three fish included.  Just be careful you get it landed before the included shark grabs it!

author: Odeinoichus
title: High Sea Fishing Fun from LEGO City.
review:
Set #60147 Fishing Boat: Here’s another great little 25$ set from LEGO city, priced under 20$ at Costco during Christmas 2017. Is it a set worth picking up? Read on to see.

Box/Instructions

Box: Love the action shot on the front of this box, the boat is out at sea doing some deep sea fishing and there’s a shark leaping to catch a fish jumping out of the water. The back also includes a lot of fun and funny action shots, pretty decent from LEGO box designs.

Instructions: Breaking up the build into two numbered bags, this set features great instructions. They’re the same as everything we’ve seen before. You will also find a sticker sheet in this set for the details on the boat, be aware of this, sometimes it may be bent or creased while in the box.

Parts

I think the biggest thing to note in regards to parts for this set is the boat hull piece in white with a dark grey interior. Everything else is what you’d expect to see in a LEGO City set, also included is a shark and two orange LEGO fish as well as a single silver fish.

Minifigures

Boat Driver: This male Minifigure is wearing a wind breaker with a shirt underneath. He’s also got a dark maroon baseball cap and pretty much standard parts for the rest of him. The trouble with LEGO City Minifigures is a lot of guys are wearing mirrored shades, or mustaches, or stubble, LEGO really gets their money worth for the standard LEGO City based facial prints.

Fisherperson: Perhaps she’s Mary, the person the boat was named for, either way she’s fairly typical as well. Her torso print features a warm looking zipped up jacket. Everything else is also standard and what you’ve come to expect from LEGO City. Both have the life vest accessory.

The build

Bag 1: This portion of the build features the two Minifigures a small buoy and the entire lower portion of the boat. There isn’t much to worry about here aside from the placement of the stickers on the side of the boat, these are large stickers and cover a fair bit of the surface of the lower hull, affixing them properly may require help for younger builders.

Bag 2: This portion of the build involves the twin motors and the rest of the interior detailing for the boat itself. This build is slightly repetitive and does not feature anything too difficult. A few more stickers to place, but nothing really troublesome.

The completed model

As my first exposure to LEGO boats in a very long time, my last boat was one of the old Pirates smaller ships, I have to say this is a fairly nice looking LEGO ship. It does not really float according to the box.

I like the overall look of the boat, it’s a nice little two-person vessel and features a decent fishing chair that you may remember Quint using in the film Jaws… Much like the Orca I’d definitely say if they’re fishing for sharks they’ll need a bigger boat. Incidentally it is called the Mary according to the sticker on the ship.

Overall opinion

This is a decent looking set, and a great price on sale during the holidays last year. I enjoyed the build and the overall look of the model really stands out, it’s a nice addition to my collection, however is it for everybody? LEGO Harbor fans might enjoy it more than casual builders. I’d still recommend this set, it’s a fun toy and involves some decent play features with the rotating chair that assist in fishing and the inclusion of a shark is very nice. Recommended.

author: Gerbil
title: Sleek look, great colours, and that shark!
review:
I bought this principally to flesh out the bay area of my town, and I needed more 'normal' boats so this seemed to fit the bill.

Pros:

  • A new (to me) shark model with enough space in the mouth for an entire fish - you really can catch the shark!
  • Great colour scheme on the boat.
  • Storage space for caught fish.
  • Speaking of fish, 3 in 2 colours is not to be sniffed at.
  • Female fisherman (fisherwoman?) - as I bought this along with #60149, this pushing of female protagonists is notable and very much welcome.
  • Meaty twin motors.
  • Accurate fishing seat.

Cons:

  • Stickers on the side of the boat hull are quite big and can be a pain to align decently.
  • The bouy isn't much use and doesn't add to the playability.
  • Although you can take the roof off the cabin, it doesn't give you as much space as you'd like for placing figures which can be fiddly as a result.

Overall impression:

This is a nice model, and fits into any water-based scene with ease. It doesn't have too much playability, although the shark is so nice that that alone accounts for much of the fun here!

As an adult the boat floating isn't really a plus, but I'm sure some kids will get more out of this set playability-wise than me as a result.

author: lentil
title: Solid set despite lackluster graphics
review:
This little set packs quite the punch for the money! It is an unusual offering, with an intermediate-sized sea-worthy vessel that is much smaller than an oceanliner but larger than the ubiquitous small rowboats in Legoland.

Pros:

  • Wonderful large, floating hull piece.
  • Totally fab color scheme in Earth Red, two shades of gray, and white, with just the right amount of bright yellow accents. There are a fair number of interestingly shaped tile and plate pieces in Earth Red which are great additions to your piece collection.
  • Superbly elegant design - the long thin hull and the streamlined, small roof canopy create sweet clean lines for the overall shape of the vessel. I also think the twin outboard motors are very attractively done.
  • Multiple fun movable elements: the yellow chair spins around 360 degrees to enable the fisherperson to angle their rod in any direction, and the fishing rod can be anchored to the chair while they're waiting for a bite. This rod anchor is also hinged to allow the rod to be angled vertically up and down, to easily maneuver to that perfect fishing spot. The end of the fishing line can be snapped to the nose of a fish, or clasped inside the shark's jaws, to really catch some seafood. The sonar machine on the roof spins around, as do the propellers on the outboard motors. The two motors can be hinged up or lowered into the water at various angles, just like real boat motors. Finally, there are two small open compartments at the back of the boat where the fresh catch can be stored. Up to two fish can fit in each compartment.
  • Two minifigures (one female, one male, both quite cute) are included, as well as a shark and three fish! That's quite a haul for a small set!

Cons:

  • The only criticism I have of this set is the stickers. Usually (like many AFOLs) I gripe incessantly about the use of stickers rather than printed pieces (while simultaneously complaining that the sets are too expensive, lol...), but grudgingly appreciate the fantastic graphic elements that stickers add to a set. This time, however, I think the set would have been better off without stickers/graphics entirely. The two stickers on the side of the hull have a cartoonish design which I find decidedly garish and unattractive. They just don't seem to harmonize at all with what is otherwise a beautiful, elegantly designed set. The rest of the stickers are so dull and non-descript that I really wonder why they bothered including them at all. The two fish storage coolers have thin black square outlines that look vaguely like a sketchy doorfront - barely visible and pretty pointless. The back of the hull has a sticker inscribed with the word "Mary" and a thin scrolly black wave. This one rather looks to me like it was done with internet clipart or a word processor font, rather than by a professional graphic artist. The sonar screen has a small sticker showing some teensy dot-like fish, reminiscent of a 1980s low-resolution video game. This is a cute touch in theory, but so small in reality that it is almost invisible. Overall the stickers here seem to be of uninspired design, and either don't contribute much or even detract from the overall look of the set. You may want to consider not applying them (too late for me unfortunately).

Despite the above sticker rant, I do think this set is a very good "catch" indeed! At only $20 RRP, it offers an incredible amount of detailed elements, fun playable features, and makes a lovely display piece for your LEGO harbor or sea-scape. If you can find one on sale, the value moves into incredible territory.
